items.title: South Korea will bring home 300 workers detained in massive Hyundai plant raid in Georgia

items.content: South Korea says it has reached a deal with the U.S. for the release of South Korean workers detained in an immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in Georgia

items.content: Some 400 US agents took part in the immigration raid on the Hyundai facility, detaining hundreds of workers, many South Korean nationals.

items.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
items.standfirst: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...

items.title: South Korea says it reached a deal to release workers detained in ICE raid
items.standfirst: South Korea says it reached a deal with the U.S. to release more than 300 South Koreans detained in an immigration enforcement raid at a Georgia Hyundai plant.
items.content: South Korea says it reached a deal with the U.S. to release more than 300 South Koreans detained in an immigration enforcement raid at a Georgia Hyundai plant.

items.title: South Korea says it has reached a deal with the US for the release of workers in a Georgia plant
items.standfirst: More than 300 South Korean workers were detained in an immigration raid on Thursday. Presidential chief of staff Kang Hoon-sik said South Korea plans to send a charter plane to bring the workers home.
items.content: More than 300 South Korean workers were detained in an immigration raid on Thursday. Presidential chief of staff Kang Hoon-sik said South Korea plans to send a charter plane to bring the workers home.(Image credit: Corey Bullard)

items.title: South Korea vows 'all-out efforts' to help hundreds detained in Hyundai raid
items.standfirst: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.
items.content: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.

items.title: Seoul promises to help hundreds of Korean workers arrested in US in Ice raid
items.standfirst: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...
items.content: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...

ai_summary: South Korea secured an agreement with the United States for worker release.
The deal involves the release of over 300 South Korean workers.
These workers were detained during an immigration raid in Georgia.
The raid occurred at a Hyundai plant in the state of Georgia.
South Korea is sending a plane to bring the workers home.

items.title: The saint who played ‘Halo’
items.standfirst: Meet the Catholic Church’s first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, who was officially canonized yesterday. Acutis died in 2006, at age 15, from leukemia. In his lifetime, he was known for using his computer skills to spread Catholicism, proving technology can be a beat-iful thing. “God’s…

items.title: Pope Leo canonizes 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church's first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St. Peter’s Square on Sunday. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports at the Vatican.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St. Peter’s Square on Sunday. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports at the Vatican.

items.title: Thousands flock to Vatican as teenager made first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.
items.content: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.

items.title: Carlo Acutis, ‘God’s influencer’ who died age 15, declared a saint by Pope Leo
items.standfirst: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...
items.content: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...

items.title: Pope declares 'God's influencer' first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.

items.title: Pope Leo declares Italian teen computer whiz a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.

Acutis was known for spreading Catholicism online.
The canonization occurred in St Peter's Square.

clusters.title: Tom Phillips, fugitive father on run with children for nearly four years, shot dead by NZ police in exchange of fire
clusters.neutral_headline: Fugitive Father Killed by Police After Confrontation

items.title: Tom Phillips, fugitive father on run with children for nearly four years, shot dead by NZ police in exchange of fire
items.standfirst: Phillips, who has been on the run with his children for four years, was shot by police after officers came under fire while investigating burglary in Piopio, authorities saidNew Zealand police search for missing children after shooting – latest updatesA fugitive father who had been hiding in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children for nearly four years has been shot dead by police investigating an armed burglary, police said on Monday.The whereabouts of Tom Phillips has attracted headlines around the world since just before Christmas 2021, when he fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a custody dispute with their mother. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Carlos Alcaraz dominates Jannik Sinner in US Open final to win 6th grand slam
clusters.neutral_headline: Carlos Alcaraz Wins US Open, Defeats Jannik Sinner

items.title: Carlos Alcaraz dominates Jannik Sinner in US Open final to win 6th grand slam
items.standfirst: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in the US Open final. He claims his sixth Grand Slam title.
items.content: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in the US Open final. He claims his sixth Grand Slam title.

items.title: Carlos Alcaraz claims 2nd U.S. Open trophy
items.standfirst: Carlos Alcaraz claimed his sixth major trophy overall at the U.S. Open on Sunday after defeating No. 1 Jannik Sinner.
items.content: Carlos Alcaraz claimed his sixth major trophy overall at the U.S. Open on Sunday after defeating No. 1 Jannik Sinner.

items.title: Alcaraz beats Sinner to lift US Open 2025 trophy as Trump watches on
items.standfirst: Alcaraz returns to number one spot after winning his sixth Grand Slam title and second of 2025 in four sets in New York.
items.content: Alcaraz returns to number one spot after winning his sixth Grand Slam title and second of 2025 in four sets in New York.

items.title: Alcaraz edges Sinner trilogy to win US Open
items.standfirst: Carlos Alcaraz triumphs in the latest chapter of his compelling rivalry with Jannik Sinner, earning a four-set victory to regain the US Open title.
items.content: Carlos Alcaraz triumphs in the latest chapter of his compelling rivalry with Jannik Sinner, earning a four-set victory to regain the US Open title.

items.title: Alcaraz beats Sinner to win US Open title, secures world number one ranking
items.standfirst: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in four sets to win his second US Open title and reclaim the world number one ranking on Sunday. The 22-year-old Spaniard produced a dazzling display of athleticism and shot-making to overpower Sinner in their third Grand Slam final of the season.
items.content: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in four sets to win his second US Open title and reclaim the world number one ranking on Sunday. The 22-year-old Spaniard produced a dazzling display of athleticism and shot-making to overpower Sinner in their third Grand Slam final of the season.

items.title: US Open final 2025 updates: Alcaraz beats Sinner 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4
items.standfirst: Alcaraz wins his second Grand Slam of the year by beating Sinner in the US Open men's singles final in New York.
items.content: Alcaraz wins his second Grand Slam of the year by beating Sinner in the US Open men's singles final in New York.

items.title: Sabalenka retains US Open title with straight-sets win over Anisimova
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka sealed back-to-back titles at Flushing Meadows by seeing off Amanda Anisimova in straight sets (6-3, 7-6) on Saturday evening. Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, meanwhile, are preparing to face off in a Grand Slam final for the third time this season on Sunday.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka sealed back-to-back titles at Flushing Meadows by seeing off Amanda Anisimova in straight sets (6-3, 7-6) on Saturday evening. Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, meanwhile, are preparing to face off in a Grand Slam final for the third time this season on Sunday.

ai_summary: Carlos Alcaraz won the US Open men's singles title.
He defeated Jannik Sinner in the final match.
Alcaraz secured his sixth Grand Slam title.
The match was played in four sets.
Alcaraz regained the world number one ranking.

clusters.title: French PM Bayrou Poised to Lose Confidence Vote
clusters.neutral_headline: French Prime Minister Faces Confidence Vote Loss

items.title: French PM Bayrou Poised to Lose Confidence Vote
items.standfirst: Francois Bayrou's government will likely fall Monday as the French Prime Minister faces a confidence motion in the nation's lower ...
items.content: Francois Bayrou's government will likely fall Monday as the French Prime Minister faces a confidence motion in the nation's lower ...

items.title: Live: French PM Bayrou fights for survival in confidence vote over austerity budget
items.standfirst: France’s parliament looks likely to remove Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday, following only nine months in office, after the PM surprised even his own allies by calling a confidence vote to resolve a months-long deadlock over his austerity budget. Should Bayrou lose, he must resign along with his entire government, plunging France into new political turmoil. Follow FRANCE 24’s liveblog for the latest details.
items.content: France’s parliament looks likely to remove Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday, following only nine months in office, after the PM surprised even his own allies by calling a confidence vote to resolve a months-long deadlock over his austerity budget. Should Bayrou lose, he must resign along with his entire government, plunging France into new political turmoil. Follow FRANCE 24’s liveblog for the latest details.

items.title: French PM Bayrou braces for confidence vote loss

clusters.title: Russia lands symbolic blow as largest aerial attack on Ukraine's capital shows Moscow's strategy
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Launches Largest Aerial Attack on Ukraine

items.title: Russia lands symbolic blow as largest aerial attack on Ukraine's capital shows Moscow's strategy
items.standfirst: The smoke spiralling above Kyiv's Cabinet of Ministers building was a stark reminder of the brutal calculus underpinning Russia's war in Ukraine.
items.content: The smoke spiralling above Kyiv's Cabinet of Ministers building was a stark reminder of the brutal calculus underpinning Russia's war in Ukraine.

items.title: Ukraine government building damaged in large Russia aerial attack
items.standfirst: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.
items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.

items.title: Russia hits Ukraine with more that 800 drones and decoy drones in biggest-ever aerial barrage
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.

items.title: Record Russian drone attack pounds Ukraine, damaging government building
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.

ai_summary: Russia launched a large aerial attack on Ukraine.

items.content: It’s been a year since Brian Niccol took the top job at Starbucks and promised change after years of bitter fighting with the company’s burgeoning union. “I deeply respect the right of partners to choose, through a fair and democratic process, to be represented by a union,” Niccol wrote in a…

items.title: A year under CEO Niccol: Starbucks workers’ long fight for a union contract
items.standfirst: Twelve months since Brian Niccol took the top job and promised change, the union and CEO are still at loggerheadsIt’s been a year since Brian Niccol took the top job at Starbucks and promised change after years of bitter fighting with the company’s burgeoning union.“I deeply respect the right of partners to choose, through a fair and democratic process, to be represented by a union,” Niccol wrote in a letter to the union last September. “If our partners choose to be represented, I am committed to making sure we engage constructively and in good faith with the union and the partners it represents.” Continue reading...
items.content: Twelve months since Brian Niccol took the top job and promised change, the union and CEO are still at loggerheadsIt’s been a year since Brian Niccol took the top job at Starbucks and promised change after years of bitter fighting with the company’s burgeoning union.“I deeply respect the right of partners to choose, through a fair and democratic process, to be represented by a union,” Niccol wrote in a letter to the union last September. “If our partners choose to be represented, I am committed to making sure we engage constructively and in good faith with the union and the partners it represents.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Brian Niccol has been CEO for one year.
Starbucks workers are still fighting for a contract.
Niccol promised change after union battles.
Niccol respects the right to union representation.
The union and CEO are still at odds.

items.title: Thousands of Bolsonaro supporters rally in Brazil as coup trial verdict nears
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of supporters of Brazil’s former president Jair Bolsonaro marched on Sunday during Independence Day, protesting against the Supreme Court ahead of its verdict this week in his alleged coup trial. Waving flags and chanting, demonstrators accused the court of bias, underscoring deep political divisions in Brazil.

items.title: Israel’s top court says government is not giving Palestinian prisoners enough food
items.standfirst: Justices rule state is legally obliged to ensure ‘basic level of existence’ and orders authorities to improve nutritionIsrael’s supreme court has ruled that the government has failed to provide Palestinian security prisoners with adequate food for basic subsistence and ordered authorities to improve their nutrition.Sunday’s decision was a rare case in which the country’s highest court ruled against the government’s conduct during the nearly two-year war. items.standfirst: President says ‘the Israelis have accepted my terms’ and urges release of hostages to secure peace agreementDonald Trump on Sunday issued what he called his “last warning” to Hamas, urging the Palestinian militant group to accept a deal to release hostages from Gaza.“The Israelis have accepted my Terms. It is time for Hamas to accept as well,” Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform. “I have warned Hamas about the consequences of not accepting. This is my last warning, there will not be another one!” Continue reading...
